questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the physician with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He has also had a burning sensation on urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not had urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. The penis appears normal, with no discharge at the meatus. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count; urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. A Gram stain of a urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of sexually transmitted infections like epididymitis in young sexually active males. N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogen that would have shown up as diplococci on Gram staining. Additionally, this patient has no history of purulent urethral discharge, which is common in males with gonorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydatid of Morgagni torsion would also cause acute scrotal pain. But it does not cause dysuria and the ultrasound would not show increased vascularity, but rather an enlarged hydatid along with normal testes.

C) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion commonly presents with acute scrotal pain and swelling, as seen in this man, but Prehn's sign is typically negative and the testicle is usually high-riding, unlike in this patient. Additionally, testicular torsion does not involve dysuria, and the Doppler ultrasound would show reduced (!) perfusion to the affected testicle.

D) CORRECT:

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. C. trachomatis can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Treatment of C. trachomatis epididymitis consists of ceftriaxone and doxycycline (see “Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain” table).

E) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a common cause of epididymitis in prepubertal boys, men > 35 years, and men who engage in anal intercourse. But this sexually active young man has no such risk factors. Moreover, E. coli would have likely shown up as gram-negative rods on Gram staining.

F) INCORRECT:

Varicocele can present with acute scrotal pain, as seen in this man, but it does not cause dysuria and leukocytes on urethral swab. Palpation of a varicocele often reveals the dilated pampiniform venous plexus. Additionally, ultrasound would clearly show the dilated hypoechoic veins, which is not the case here.
questions.hint: This sexually active young man has dysuria, a tender testicle, a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), and increased blood flow to the testicle on ultrasonography, indicating epididymitis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of severe left testicular pain for 1 hour. For the past week, he has also had mild testicular pain and pain on urination. He has not had nausea or vomiting. He is otherwise healthy. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Examination shows a high-riding, swollen, erythematous tender left testis; lifting the left testis relieves his pain. His hemoglobin concentration is 15.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 14,600/mm3, and platelet count is 290,000/mm3. Testicular ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the left testicle when compared to the right and an enlarged left epididymis with decreased echogenicity. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A reducible scrotal mass occurs in patients with an inguinal hernia. These hernias are typically not painful. Painful scrotal swelling in combination with a fever, dysuria, increased inflammatory markers, and this patient's ultrasound findings are not consistent with an inguinal hernia.

Inguinal hernias can become painful if complications such as strangulation or incarceration occur. However, inguinal hernias are usually no longer reducible by the time complications set in.

B) INCORRECT:

Swelling of the parotid gland may be caused by infectious diseases, autoimmune diseases (e.g., Sjögren's syndrome), bulimia, or salivary gland tumors. If caused by mumps, orchitis may also occur, which would present with testicular pain and swelling. However, dysuria and the presence of an enlarged epididymis on ultrasound make epididymitis with associated urethritis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod that is a common cause of epididymitis in prepubertal boys, males > 35 years, and men who are the insertive partner during anal intercourse. In this 15-year-old postpubertal patient, an infection with a different pathogen is more likely.

D) CORRECT:

The most likely causative agents of epididymitis in a patient between 15 and 35 years of age are Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. If a pubertal or postpubertal patient presents with signs of infection such as urethritis and fever, infection with a sexually transmitted pathogen should be considered even if the patient denies sexual activity. Both infections are diagnosed with nucleic acid amplification testing. Other causes of infectious epididymitis, especially in prepubertal boys or adolescents who are not sexually active, include Mycoplasma pneumoniae, enteroviruses, and adenoviruses.

This patient's ultrasound findings of intact blood flow also rule out testicular torsion, which should always be suspected in a patient presenting with acute unilateral testicular pain. Prehn sign was once believed to be helpful in differentiating between testicular torsion and epididymitis. Nowadays, Doppler ultrasound of the testicle is of much higher diagnostic value.

E) INCORRECT:

A cremasteric reflex is often absent in patients with testicular torsion, which mostly affects neonates and boys during puberty and is also associated with acute scrotal pain, swelling, and an elevated testicle. However, a positive Prehn sign, dysuria, and increased inflammatory markers make testicular torsion unlikely. An ultrasound showing intact or increased blood flow basically rules out testicular torsion, which typically shows reduced perfusion of the affected testicle and twisting of the spermatic cord instead.
questions.hint: This patient's combination of unilateral testicular pain and swelling, fever, dysuria, leukocytosis, and a positive Prehn sign (pain relief upon lifting the testicle) indicate epididymitis. Ultrasound findings of increased blood flow to the left testicle and an enlarged epididymis with decreased echogenicity support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressive left-sided scrotal pain for 4 hours. He describes the pain as throbbing in nature and 6 out of 10 in intensity. He has vomited once on the way to the hospital. He has had pain during urination for the past 4 days. He had an episode of similar pain 1 year ago that resolved spontaneously. He underwent surgery for a left-sided inguinal hernia as a child. He has been sexually active with 2 female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears anxious. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination shows a tender, swollen left testicle and a firm and erythematous left hemiscrotum. The left testicle ascends when the medial portion of the left thigh is stroked. Urine dipstick shows positive leukocyte esterase. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin) can be used to treat epididymitis in older patients, in whom this condition is most commonly secondary to urinary tract infections. Since epididymitis in young, sexually active male individuals is most frequently caused by sexually transmitted infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a combination of ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment for this patient. Moreover, his presentation makes a different step in management necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is typically used in the workup of an acute abdomen. It may also be used in the workup of suspected torsion of an undescended testis. Imaging modalities such as CT scan, MRI, and scintigraphy play no role in the initial workup of this patient who has symptoms of an acute scrotum and no cryptorchidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical exploration is indicated if clinical features indicate a definitive diagnosis of testicular torsion. Although this patient's presentation increases the likelihood of testicular torsion, the diagnosis of testicular torsion is not yet conclusive at this time because of an intact cremasteric reflex, the absence of a hard and high-riding testis, and the presence of features of epididymitis. A different step in management should be performed first.

D) CORRECT:

While epididymitis is the most likely cause of this patient's acute testicular pain, the most dangerous differential diagnosis is testicular torsion. In patients with acute testicular pain, an absent cremasteric reflex is relatively specific for testicular torsion but the presence of a cremasteric reflex does not rule out the condition. For this patient, a scrotal ultrasound is necessary to definitively rule out testicular torsion. If testicular torsion is not corrected early by surgery, testicular ischemia will result in necrosis and loss of the testicle. Scrotal ultrasound is also performed as a part of the management of epididymitis in order to rule out a scrotal abscess, a common complication that may require surgical drainage.

Risk stratification scores (e.g., TWIST score) can be used to formally assess the risk of testicular torsion. For your exam, it is not necessary to know how to calculate the TWIST score but to follow this principle: always consider testicular torsion in a patient with acute testicular pain and if testicular torsion cannot be ruled out clinically with a high level of certainty, perform a scrotal ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

Orchitis can manifest with a unilateral swollen and tender testicle in conjunction with nausea and vomiting. Orchitis may be a complication of infection with the mumps virus, which can be confirmed by positive serology (e.g., IgG antibody titer). However, in mumps orchitis, a sudden onset of fever is expected. Furthermore, the classic course of mumps infection includes a prodromal phase with low-grade fever, respiratory symptoms, malaise, and headache, followed by parotitis, which is not consistent with this patient's clinical presentation.
questions.hint: This patient's high risk sexual behavior, dysuria, and pyuria (positive leukocyte esterase) are consistent with epididymitis but his young age, the sudden onset of scrotal pain, and the presence of vomiting and testicular swelling also increase the likelihood of a condition that can result in permanent morbidity if not detected and treated within 6 hours of symptom onset.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician with throbbing right scrotal pain for 1 day. He has also had a burning sensation on urination during the last 4 days. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and does not use condoms. Physical examination shows a tender, palpable swelling on the upper pole of the right testicle; lifting the testicle relieves the pain. A Gram stain of urethral secretions shows numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a very common cause of epididymitis in men below the age of 35 years. It causes pain and swelling of the testis and a positive Prehn sign. However, Gram stain would show gram-negative, aerobic, facultative intracellular diplococci.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause urinary tract infection, which again can lead to epididymitis. However, this mostly affects prepubertal boys and older males. Additionally, P. aeruginosa would have shown up as a gram-negative, rod-shaped organism on Gram stain.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a nonmotile, aerobic, gram-positive, acid-fast bacillus with a rich lipid cell wall that causes chronic epididymitis (> 6-week course of disease). Symptoms include scrotal pain and swelling. However, compared to acute epididymitis, swelling would be minimal, and there would be a history of recurrent or untreated epididymitis. Also, the patient has no risk factors for TB like immunosuppression, drug or alcohol abuse, or travel to a region with higher rates.

D) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum is a rare cause of epididymitis and it is most known for causing syphilis. This patient does exhibit high-risk sexual behavior, making STD very likely. Furthermore, T. pallidum would not show up on Gram stain. However, this patient does not have any findings indicative of syphilis such as a painless lesion on the penile shaft, and since T. pallidum is a rare cause of epididymitis, a different pathogen is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Mumps virus would cause orchitis, which would present with inflammation of one or both testes, causing pain and swelling of testis without an identifiable organism on Gram stain. However, it would also present with sudden onset of fever, nausea, vomiting, and signs of parotitis (cheek pain and swelling). In addition, peak incidence would be between 5–14 years of age.

F) CORRECT:

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. It can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Because coinfection is common, empiric treatment of acute epididymitis in this patient involves ceftriaxone and doxycycline to cover both pathogens.

G) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus might cause folliculitis, a localized inflammation of the hair follicle or sebaceous glands that is characterized by erythema, tender papules, and/or pustules at the site of hair follicles. Infection can occur due to shaving, causing local pain and swelling. However, Gram stain would show a gram-positive and coagulase-positive coccus and negative Prehn sign.

H) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of urinary tract infection, which can lead to epididymitis. However, this mostly affects prepubertal boys and older males. Another cause is much more likely in this young, sexually active male.
questions.hint: This young man, who engages in high-risk sexual behavior, has dysuria, a tender swelling on the right testicle, and a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), indicating epididymitis.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute-onset pain in his genital area. He has had no recent trauma and has not had any dysuria, rash, or penile discharge. He had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago and has a slightly runny nose, but he has been afebrile and he has no other symptoms.
On examination, his temperature is 36.5°C, and his vital signs are normal. The right side of his scrotum appears to be red and swollen. The testicle is in the scrotal sac and is tender to palpation. There is a normal cremasteric reflex on the right.
Urinalysis reveals no leukocytes or blood. An ultrasound reveals increased blood flow to the right epididymis.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urgent urology referral would be necessary if testicular torsion were suspected, as that would be a surgical emergency. This patient's intact cremasteric reflex and ultrasound findings make testicular torsion unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

In sexually active males, gonorrhea and chlamydia are frequent causes of epididymitis, and a urethral swab and empiric treatment with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is indicated. Epididymitis in prepubertal boys is not typically caused by a sexually transmitted infection. Unless there are other reasons to suspect sexual abuse, a urethral swab, empiric antibiotic treatment, and referral to child protective services are not warranted.

C) INCORRECT:

In sexually active males, gonorrhea and chlamydia are frequent causes of epididymitis, and a urethral swab and empiric treatment with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is indicated. Epididymitis in prepubertal boys is not typically caused by a sexually transmitted infection. Unless there are other reasons to suspect sexual abuse, a urethral swab, empiric antibiotic treatment, and referral to child protective services are not warranted. If the urinalysis is suggestive of infection, empiric treatment with antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or cephalexin would be appropriate until urine-culture results are available.

D) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis in prepubertal boys is not typically caused by a sexually transmitted infection. Unless there are other reasons to suspect sexual abuse, a urethral swab, empiric antibiotic treatment, and referral to child protective services are not warranted.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history and physical findings are consistent with epididymitis. The pain associated with this condition can be acute or subacute and is often preceded by a viral illness. Examination of the affected testis will reveal tenderness to palpation, with possible redness and swelling, and the cremasteric reflex is present. Ultrasound will show increased blood flow to the affected epididymis.

If the urinalysis is negative in a patient with suspected epididymitis (as in this case), the appropriate treatment is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, rest, and scrotal elevation.

If the urinalysis is suggestive of infection, empiric treatment with antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or cephalexin would be appropriate until urine-culture results are available.

Key learning point: The most appropriate care for a prepubertal boy with suspected epididymitis, a negative urinalysis, and an intact cremasteric reflex is rest, scrotal elevation, and ibuprofen.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 17-year-old boy comes to the office with left-sided testicular pain for the past 2 days that began gradually and is moderate in intensity. In addition, the patient reports urinary frequency and burning with urination. He has had no fever, nausea, abdominal pain, or urethral discharge. He takes no regular medications but has been using ibuprofen 400 mg every 8 hours with insufficient relief. He is sexually active with his girlfriend, who uses oral contraceptive pills for pregnancy prevention.
His vital signs are stable. On physical examination, the testes are positioned normally and are equal in size with no visible lesions. The left side of the scrotum is erythematous and edematous. Palpation of the area posterior to the left testicle is painful, but no masses are evident. The cremasteric reflex is present bilaterally. There is tender inguinal lymphadenopathy on the left side.
Urinalysis yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Specific gravity
1.020
1.001–1.035


pH
6.5
5.0–9.0


Glucose
Negative
Negative


Urobilinogen
Negative
Negative


Bilirubin
Negative
Negative


Ketones
Negative
Negative


Occult blood
Negative
Negative


Protein
1+
Negative


Nitrites
Negative
Negative


Leukocyte esterase
2+
Negative


Leukocytes (per high-power field)
10
0–2


Erythrocytes (per high-power field)
None seen
0–2


Squamous epithelial cells
None seen
None


Bacteria
None seen
None


A urine sample is sent out for culture and nucleic acid amplification testing.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In non-sexually active adolescents with epididymitis thought to be caused by enteric bacteria, treatment with a fluoroquinolone (e.g., levofloxacin) is appropriate. Epididymitis in sexually active adolescents is most commonly caused by an STI, which requires a different treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's condition should be managed with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs for pain control. Opioids are not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent surgical exploration is indicated in patients with testicular torsion, which most commonly occurs in teenagers and manifests with acute scrotal pain and swelling. However, patients with testicular torsion typically have no urinary symptoms, an absent cremasteric reflex, a transverse and high-riding testicle, and experience nausea, vomiting, and sudden onset of severe pain that is aggravated by scrotal support and elevation. This patient's condition does not require surgery.

D) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has epididymitis, which classically manifests with gradual onset of nonsevere, unilateral, posterior scrotal pain. Some patients also present with fever, lower abdominal pain, urethral discharge, dysuria, hematuria, urinary frequency and/or urinary urgency. On physical examination, the testicles are positioned normally, the epididymis is tender and swollen, and the cremasteric reflex is preserved. Scrotal erythema and inguinal lymphadenopathy may also be present.

Urinalysis should be performed for all patients with suspected epididymitis, which may show pyuria. Urine culture is usually negative. If the patient is sexually active, nucleic acid amplification testing should be performed on urine or urethral discharge. If the diagnosis is uncertain, Doppler ultrasound can be used to confirm increased blood flow to the enlarged epididymis.

Epididymitis can be infectious or noninfectious. In sexually active adolescents, the most common pathogens are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Men who practice insertive anal intercourse are also at risk for Escherichia coli infection. In children and non-sexually active adolescents, bacterial epididymitis is rare unless there is a structural abnormality leading to urinary reflux of enteric pathogens (e.g., E. coli). Epididymitis in children is more commonly due to viral pathogens (e.g., adenovirus or enteroviruses). Urinary reflux of enteric pathogens due to urinary obstruction (e.g., benign prostate hypertrophy) is the most common cause in older men. Noninfectious causes of epididymitis include trauma and autoimmune diseases. The exact cause is often unknown.

All patients with epididymitis should be managed with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs for pain control, scrotal support and elevation, and rest. In patients with a suspected STI, empiric antibiotic therapy for gonorrhea and chlamydia (i.e., ceftriaxone and doxycycline) is indicated. Patients who practice insertive anal sex should be treated with ceftriaxone plus a fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin.

Key learning point: Epididymitis is characterized by gradual onset of nonsevere, unilateral, posterior scrotal pain and edema, and a normal testicular lie and cremasteric reflex. Sexually active adolescents with this condition should be treated empirically for gonorrhea and chlamydia with ceftriaxone and doxycycline.

E) INCORRECT:

For prepubertal children with epididymitis and pyuria and/or a positive urine culture, treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or cephalexin is appropriate. Epididymitis in sexually active adolescents is most commonly caused by an STI, which requires a different treatment.

questions.hint: This patient's history and physical findings are consistent with epididymitis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the office with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He has also had a burning sensation on urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not had urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. The penis appears normal, with no discharge at the meatus. Urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. A Gram stain of a urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of sexually transmitted infections like epididymitis in young sexually active males. N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogen that would have shown up as diplococci on Gram staining. Additionally, this patient has no history of purulent urethral discharge, which is common in males with gonorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion commonly presents with acute scrotal pain and swelling, as seen in this man, but Prehn's sign is typically negative and the testicle is usually high-riding, unlike in this patient. In addition, the patient reports urinary frequency and burning with urination. He is sexually active with his girlfriend, who uses oral contraceptive pills for pregnancy prevention. On physical examination, the testes are positioned normally and are equal in size with no visible lesions. The left side of the scrotum is erythematous and edematous. Palpation of the area posterior to the left testicle is painful, but no masses are evident. The cremasteric reflex is present bilaterally. There is tender inguinal lymphadenopathy on the left side. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
Negative


Protein
1+


Nitrites
Negative


Leukocyte esterase
2+


WBC
10/hpf


Bacteria
Negative


A urine sample is sent out for culture and nucleic acid amplification testing. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In non-sexually active adolescents with epididymitis thought to be caused by enteric bacteria, treatment with a fluoroquinolone (e.g., levofloxacin) is appropriate. Epididymitis in sexually active adolescents is most commonly caused by an STI, which requires a different treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's condition should be managed with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs for pain control. Opioids are not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent surgical exploration is indicated in patients with testicular torsion, which most commonly occurs in teenagers and manifests with acute scrotal pain and swelling. However, patients with testicular torsion typically have no urinary symptoms, an absent cremasteric reflex, a transverse and high-riding testicle, and experience nausea, vomiting, and sudden onset of severe pain that is aggravated by scrotal support and elevation. This patient's condition does not require surgery.

D) CORRECT:

Some patients with epididymitis present with fever, lower abdominal pain, urethral discharge, dysuria, hematuria, urinary frequency and/or urinary urgency. On physical examination, the testicles are positioned normally, the epididymis is tender and swollen, and the cremasteric reflex is preserved. Urinalysis should be performed for all patients with suspected epididymitis, which may show pyuria. Urine culture is usually negative. If the patient is sexually active, nucleic acid amplification testing should be performed on urine or urethral discharge.

All patients with epididymitis should be managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain control, scrotal support and elevation, and rest. In patients with a suspected STI, empiric antibiotic therapy for gonorrhea and chlamydia (i.e., ceftriaxone and doxycycline) is indicated. Patients who practice insertive anal sex should be treated with ceftriaxone plus a fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin.

Key learning point: Epididymitis is characterized by gradual onset of nonsevere, unilateral, posterior scrotal pain and edema, and a normal testicular lie and cremasteric reflex. Sexually active adolescents with this condition should be treated empirically for gonorrhea and chlamydia with ceftriaxone and doxycycline.

E) INCORRECT:

For prepubertal children with epididymitis and pyuria and/or a positive urine culture, treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or cephalexin is appropriate. Epididymitis in sexually active adolescents is most commonly caused by an STI, which requires a different treatment.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has epididymitis, which classically manifests with gradual onset of nonsevere, unilateral, posterior scrotal pain.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-day history of throbbing right scrotal pain. He also reports a burning sensation on urination for the past 4 days. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and does not use condoms. On examination, there is a tender, palpable swelling at the upper pole of the right testicle, and lifting the testicle relieves the pain. Gram stain of urethral secretions reveals numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Which one of the following is the most likely causal pathogen for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. It can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Because coinfection is common, empiric treatment of acute epididymitis in this patient involves ceftriaxone and doxycycline to cover both pathogens.

Key learning point: In sexually active men under 35, epididymitis is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae, with Chlamydia suspected when Gram stain shows no organisms.

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a very common cause of epididymitis in men below the age of 35 years. It causes pain and swelling of the testis and a positive Prehn sign. However, Gram stain would show gram-negative, aerobic, facultative intracellular diplococci.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus might cause folliculitis, a localized inflammation of the hair follicle or sebaceous glands that is characterized by erythema, tender papules, and/or pustules at the site of hair follicles. Infection can occur due to shaving, causing local pain and swelling. However, Gram stain would show a gram-positive and coagulase-positive coccus and negative Prehn sign.

D) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum is a rare cause of epididymitis and it is most known for causing syphilis. This patient does exhibit high-risk sexual behavior, making STD very likely. Furthermore, T. pallidum would not show up on Gram stain. However, this patient does not have any findings indicative of syphilis such as a painless lesion on the penile shaft, and since T. pallidum is a rare cause of epididymitis, a different pathogen is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Mumps virus would cause orchitis, which would present with inflammation of one or both testes, causing pain and swelling of testis without an identifiable organism on Gram stain. However, it would also present with sudden onset of fever, nausea, vomiting, and signs of parotitis (cheek pain and swelling). In addition, peak incidence would be between 5–14 years of age.
questions.hint: This young man, who engages in high-risk sexual behavior, has dysuria, a tender swelling on the right testicle, and a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), indicating epididymitis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to your clinic with 12 hours of dull, throbbing right-sided scrotal pain. He also reports a burning sensation with urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not noticed any urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. On examination, his right testicle is tender, and lifting it provides relief. The penis is normal in appearance, with no discharge at the meatus. Urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. Gram stain of a urethral swab reveals polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound demonstrates increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varicocele can present with acute scrotal pain, as seen in this man, but it does not cause dysuria and leukocytes on urethral swab. Palpation of a varicocele often reveals the dilated pampiniform venous plexus. Additionally, ultrasound would clearly show the dilated hypoechoic veins, which is not the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a common cause of epididymitis in prepubertal boys, men > 35 years, and men who engage in anal intercourse. But this sexually active young man has no such risk factors. Moreover, E. coli would have likely shown up as gram-negative rods on Gram staining.

C) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of sexually transmitted infections like epididymitis in young sexually active males. N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogen that would have shown up as diplococci on Gram staining. Additionally, this patient has no history of purulent urethral discharge, which is common in males with gonorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion commonly presents with acute scrotal pain and swelling, as seen in this man, but Prehn's sign is typically negative and the testicle is usually high-riding, unlike in this patient. Additionally, testicular torsion does not involve dysuria, and the Doppler ultrasound would show reduced (!) perfusion to the affected testicle.

E) CORRECT:

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. C. trachomatis can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Treatment of C. trachomatis epididymitis consists of ceftriaxone and doxycycline (see “Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain” table).

Key learning point: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of epididymitis in sexually active men under age 35, often presenting with dysuria and sterile pyuria.
questions.hint: This sexually active young man has dysuria, a tender testicle, a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), and increased blood flow to the testicle on ultrasonography, indicating epididymitis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-year-old boy in the emergency department with acute-onset genital pain. He has no history of recent trauma, dysuria, rash, or penile discharge. He had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. On examination, the right side of his scrotum is red and swollen. The right testicle is located in the scrotal sac and is tender to palpation. The cremasteric reflex is present on the right. Urinalysis is normal. Scrotal ultrasound demonstrates increased blood flow to the right epididymis. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in his care?

choices.text: Inform the provincial child welfare authority.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urgent urology referral would be necessary if testicular torsion were suspected, as that would be a surgical emergency. This patient's intact cremasteric reflex and ultrasound findings make testicular torsion unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

In prepubertal boys with epididymitis, empiric treatment with antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or cephalexin would be appropriate if the initial urinalysis is suggestive of infection (until urine-culture results are available). This patient's urinalysis results are normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis in prepubertal boys is not typically caused by a sexually transmitted infection. Unless there are other reasons to suspect sexual abuse, disclosure to the provincial child welfare authority is not warranted.

D) INCORRECT:

In sexually active males, gonorrhea and chlamydia are frequent causes of epididymitis, and a urethral swab and empiric treatment with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is indicated. Epididymitis in prepubertal boys is not typically caused by a sexually transmitted infection. Unless there are other reasons to suspect sexual abuse, a urethral swab is not warranted.

E) CORRECT:

In sexually active males, epididymitis is often caused by gonorrhea or chlamydia; in prepubertal boys, it usually follows a viral illness. The pain associated with epididymitis can be acute or subacute. Examination of the affected testis will reveal tenderness to palpation, with possible redness and swelling, and the cremasteric reflex is present. Ultrasound will show increased blood flow to the affected epididymis. If the urinalysis is negative in a patient with suspected epididymitis (as in this case), the appropriate treatment consists of NSAID therapy, rest, and scrotal elevation. If the urinalysis is suggestive of infection, empiric treatment with antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or cephalexin would be appropriate until urine-culture results are available.

Key learning point: For a prepubertal boy with epididymitis and negative urinalysis, the initial treatment consists of rest, scrotal elevation, and NSAID therapy.
questions.hint: This patient's findings are consistent with epididymitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the ED with 2 days of scrotal pain and swelling. He reports dysuria and a new sexual partner. Vital signs are BP, 124/76 mm Hg; P, 96; R, 18; T, 38.1°C (100.6°F). On exam, the scrotum is tender with erythema and swelling localized to the posterior aspect of the left testis. The cremasteric reflex is intact, and pain improves with scrotal elevation. Urinalysis shows 20–30 WBC/hpf, positive leukocyte esterase, and no nitrites. Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric treatment?

choices.text: Intramuscular ceftriaxone followed by oral doxycycline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is appropriate for epididymitis caused by enteric organisms in older men or those with recent urinary tract instrumentation. However, in young, sexually active men, levofloxacin does not provide reliable coverage for gonorrhea and is therefore not the correct empiric choice in this scenario.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — The patient’s age, new sexual partner, dysuria, and urinalysis findings suggest sexually transmitted epididymitis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis. Recommended empiric treatment in the ED is a single intramuscular dose of ceftriaxone plus 10 days of doxycycline. This covers both pathogens effectively.

C) INCORRECT:

While this agent can treat some urinary pathogens, it does not cover gonorrhea or chlamydia. Using it as empiric therapy in a young man with a likely sexually transmitted etiology risks treatment failure and ongoing infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion is an important differential diagnosis in acute scrotal pain. However, the presence of fever, urinary symptoms, intact cremasteric reflex, and pain relief with elevation strongly favor epididymitis. Immediate surgical intervention is not indicated in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis is an infectious condition that requires antibiotic treatment to prevent serious complications including abscess formation, spread to the testicle, and potential infertility. Symptomatic measures alone are insufficient and risk treatment failure with ongoing infection and complications.

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active man presents with a 3-day history of right-sided scrotal pain and swelling. He reports mild dysuria but denies fever. Physical examination shows a tender, indurated epididymis posterior to the right testis. There is scrotal erythema and a positive Prehn sign. A urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Elevated serum anti-mumps IgM antibody titer
Growth of gram-negative rods in a urine culture
Identification of spirochetes using darkfield microscopy
Presence of motile flagellates on urethral swab microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An elevated anti-mumps IgM antibody titer would indicate an acute mumps virus infection. Mumps can cause orchitis (inflammation of the testis), which manifests with testicular pain and swelling. However, mumps orchitis is typically preceded by parotitis and is less common in vaccinated individuals. This patient's findings are localized to the epididymis, making epididymitis, not orchitis, the primary diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

In sexually active men younger than 35 years, the most common causative organisms are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The recommended diagnostic test for these pathogens is a Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT), which detects specific genetic material, such as ribosomal RNA or DNA. The NAAT is highly sensitive and specific and is typically performed on a first-catch urine sample or a urethral swab. An unremarkable urinalysis does not rule out these organisms, as urethritis can be present without significant pyuria. Empiric treatment with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is typically initiated while awaiting test results.

C) INCORRECT:

Growth of gram-negative rods, such as Escherichia coli, in a urine culture would suggest epididymitis secondary to a urinary tract infection. Although this is a cause of epididymitis, it is the most common cause in patients older than 35 or in those with underlying urologic abnormalities. This patient's age, sexual activity, and unremarkable urinalysis make this a less likely cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Darkfield microscopy is used to identify the spirochete Treponema pallidum from the exudate of a chancre, which is the characteristic lesion of primary syphilis. Acute epididymitis is not a feature of syphilis. This patient's symptoms of scrotal pain, swelling, and dysuria are not consistent with a syphilitic infection.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of motile flagellates on a wet mount preparation is diagnostic for Trichomonas vaginalis. Although Trichomonas is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause urethritis and dysuria, it is a very rare cause of acute epididymitis. This patient's clinical presentation is much more suggestive of other common sexually transmitted pathogens.
questions.hint: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of acute epididymitis, which in sexually active men younger than 35 years is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a 3-day history of progressive left-sided scrotal pain and swelling. He reports mild dysuria but does not have urethral discharge or fever. He is sexually active with male partners. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F). Physical examination shows a swollen left scrotum that is exquisitely tender along the posterior aspect of the testis. The cremasteric reflex is intact, and elevation of the scrotum provides some pain relief. Urinalysis shows 15–20 WBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis and can be used in combination regimens for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. However, as monotherapy, it is insufficient for treating gonococcal infections due to resistance and provides no coverage for the enteric pathogens this patient is at risk for.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of ceftriaxone plus doxycycline is the standard first-line treatment for acute epididymitis in sexually active men younger than 35 years who do not practice insertive anal intercourse. While it provides excellent coverage for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, it does not provide reliable coverage for the enteric organisms for which this patient is at increased risk.

C) CORRECT:

For sexually active MSM who practice insertive anal intercourse, the empiric antibiotic regimen must cover both common sexually transmitted infections (e.g., Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis) and enteric organisms (e.g., Escherichia coli). The combination of a single intramuscular dose of ceftriaxone and a course of oral levofloxacin provides this necessary broad-spectrum coverage. Ceftriaxone is highly effective against N. gonorrhoeae, while levofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, is effective against enteric pathogens and also provides coverage for C. trachomatis. This regimen is recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for this specific patient population.

D) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with a fluoroquinolone like levofloxacin is the recommended treatment for acute epididymitis in men older than 35 years, in which the cause is typically non-sexually transmitted enteric organisms. However, this regimen is inadequate for this patient because it does not reliably treat Neisseria gonorrhoeae due to high rates of resistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is often used for urinary tract infections caused by enteric organisms. However, it is not recommended for acute epididymitis in this patient because it does not provide coverage for the common sexually transmitted pathogens, specifically Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Additionally, resistance rates among uropathogens can be high.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with acute epididymitis (swollen left scrotum, tender along the posterior aspect, positive Prehn sign). Men who have sex with men (MSM) are at risk for infection with enteric organisms in addition to the typical sexually transmitted pathogens.
